p: Ferutinin is a sesquiterpene, extracted from the roots, the leaves and the rhizome [ 31, 32]. Different mechanisms by which several compounds, isolated from many species of Ferula L., exert their inhibitory activity on cell growth are known [ 33]. Among the compounds isolated from many species of Ferula, ferutinin obtained from the plants Ferula ovina Boiss., Ferula communis L., Ferula hermonis Boiss., and other species of Ferula [ 34, 35], is known for the different activities that, in a dose-dependent way, performs both in vitro and in vivo ( Figure 1). In particular, ferutinin has shown estrogenic, anti-inflammatory, antiproliferative, cytotoxic [ 36], antifungal and antimicrobial activities; the cytotoxic activity represents the pivotal role of its action that should leads to the use of this molecule in anti-neoplastic therapy [ 37, 38, 39, 40].
